article.title: Smartphone market forecast to decline this year due to memory shortage

summary: Global smartphone shipments are set to decline sharply in 2026 due to an ongoing memory chip shortage, marking the lowest annual volume in over a decade. This disruption is reshaping the market landscape, with smaller and low-end Android vendors facing significant challenges while Apple and Samsung stand to gain market share.
keyPoints: Worldwide smartphone shipments forecast to drop 12.9% YoY to 1.1 billion units in 2026.
Memory shortage crisis is the primary driver, causing a structural market reset rather than a temporary disruption.
Smartphone average selling price (ASP) expected to rise 14% to a record $523 in 2026.
Low-end segment (<$100), accounting for 171 million devices, will become uneconomical due to sustained higher memory costs.
Regions with high low-end smartphone penetration, like Middle East & Africa, face steepest declines (20.6% YoY).
Modest recovery of 2% expected in 2027, with stronger 5.2% growth forecast for 2028 as memory supply stabilizes.

rewrite.title: Smartphone Shipments to Drop Sharply in 2026
rewrite.body:
The global smartphone market is poised for a significant downturn in 2026, with shipments projected to fall 12.9% year-over-year to 1.1 billion units, the lowest volume seen in more than ten years. This decline is largely driven by a severe memory chip shortage that has disrupted supply chains across the consumer electronics sector. Unlike a temporary supply hiccup, this shortage is triggering a fundamental market reset, impacting vendor dynamics and product pricing.

The memory crisis is particularly detrimental to low-end Android manufacturers, who face rising component costs that squeeze margins and force price increases. This segment, which includes devices priced under $100 and represents roughly 171 million units, is expected to become economically unviable. In contrast, dominant players like Apple and Samsung are better positioned to absorb cost pressures and may expand their market share as smaller competitors exit or shrink.

Regionally, markets with a high concentration of budget smartphones will experience the steepest shipment declines. The Middle East and Africa are forecasted to see a 20.6% drop, while China and the Asia Pacific region (excluding Japan and China) are expected to contract by 10.5% and 13.1%, respectively. Despite these challenges, average selling prices are anticipated to rise 14% to a record $523, reflecting the shift towards higher-end devices.

Looking ahead, IDC anticipates the memory supply situation to stabilize by mid-2027, enabling a modest market recovery of 2% that year, followed by a stronger rebound of 5.2% in 2028. However, the market will not revert to its previous structure, as the crisis permanently alters the total addressable market and product mix, accelerating consolidation and favoring premium vendors.
